description:
This is my favorite Peruvian restaurant in San Francisco. If you want to eat traditional Peruvian food-this is the place.

Usually, I have a hard time finding a decent Peruvian restaurant, but I have no complaints about Cholo soy:) 

If you are a foodie and like trying good food -don't let the reasonable menu prices deceive you: this is as good as it gets in SF if you are Peruvian or want to try Peruvian food.

I love good food and I am never disappointed at Cholo Soy:)
author: Torres L.

description: Excellent food and friendly service in the lobby of an office building.  Excellent ceviche and pork dishes.
author: Michael C.

description: We got there a little late and they only had one of their main dishes left on the menu. This chicken dish was phenomenal. The flavors were great and the chicken was juicy and moist. The ceviche was awesome and the sauce was very unique. The drinks were also very nice and refreshing. This is some very well executed cooking. I was very impressed.
author: Al W.

description:
As an Inca and Peruvian myself I love this place! Hard to spot at first needs a bigger sign but located right on the mission strip and has a classy interior if your on a date. The service is super friendly and quick and the food extremely authentic no mexican people serving corn based empanadas here. The prices are cheap for peruvian food as well. 

If your hungry I recomend any of the daily special meat and rice platters but this time I ordered 3 appetizers due to childhood nostalgia and a craving of peruvian sauces. I went with a crab causa rellena huancaina, ocopa potatoes, and aji amarillo ceviche.

The ocopa has sliced peruvian boiled potatoes served cold and topped with bright green black mint based ocopa sauce served warm and side of hardboiled egg and lettuce. The causa is layered mashed potatoes with a layer of meat inbetween(i chose crab) and topped hardboiled egg or olive and creamy/cheesy aji based huancaina sauce like a little cake in appearance. Aji peppers are a trademark used in most peruvian dishes and vary in heat but are usually milder and flavorful. The ceviche(raw seafood marinated in citrus pepper juice) came with alot of fish and they used an interesting yellow aji sauce for it. 

Everything was super delicious and prepared perfectly. This is one of my favorite spots in the city and dosnt require waiting in line or a reservation just walk in for dank food.
author: Sean G.

description:
I *love* Cholo Soy. My friend D and I had lunch here, and we each ordered a different ceviche and we also ordered the seco de pato and seco de cordero. Everything was so yummy and I was full for so long after cleaning my plates!

I want to go back on different days of the week to try some of the other menu items. :)
author: Jinyoung P.

description: A tiny hole in the wall in the heart of the Mission lies Cholo Soy.  This Peruvian find is the real deal.  To quench my thirst I ordered a morado, a purple maiz drink...that taste a bit like Welch 's grape juice but even better.  Their signature cerviche appetizers with the right amount of lime juice, red onions and other flavors was fresh and wonderful. Their cau cau (tripe ) was tender and flavorful.  The chicken, pork and beef were succulent and delicious.
author: Mabe S.

description: We were looking for a restaurant that ended up being temporary pop-up that had since closed and stumbled into this hole in the wall spot. It ended up being the best find during our SF trip. The food came out fast (which was good because we were already starving by then) and everything was delicious and inexpensive. Staff was very friendly as well.
author: Yarelhdi J.

description: Had the ceviche, arroz con pollo verde and seco de pollo and it was amazing. Gives a new meaning to "hole in a wall"
author: Oscar F.

description:
- Cheap lunch specials 
- FAST. My food appeared almost immediately 
- Authentic. 

The rice in particular is amazing. Marinated and mixed with beans in just the right proportions with slices of crisp red onion on top. 

The menu rotates daily so on the Tuesday I went I got arroz with pork. The rice was delicious but the pork was quite dry until I got to the meat on the bone. I usually prefer pork but wish I'd tried the chicken this time. 

The restaurant is a counter inside a mini mall with metal tables to eat at. Great for individuals or small groups
author: Sophie C.

description:
We love this place the ceviche is the best in town. Fresh and incredibly delicious.  The rest of the menu is very tasty as well.  Central location quick service and friendly staff .

Thank you cholo.
author: Quality H.

description:
As much as I want to keep this hidden gem a secret, I would feel guilty not giving them kudos. Both types of ceviche were delicious, fresh, and sooo affordable ($8.50 each).  The lamb platter ($12.99) is probably their best dish and includes a giant braised lamb leg with rice and beans. Everything was delicious and the service is stellar.  The server was sooo attentive and constantly refilled our water and brought things we kept asking for like more hot sauce, which had even had scallions in it. A bit hard to find as it's inside a corridor or lobby of a building, but still felt private. Cholo Soy is so authentic and focused on its unique dishes that it doesn't even serve the more mainstream lomo saltado, which you can get anywhere else. 

Super affordable (costs way less than the equivalent at La Mar, but a different ambiance of course), great service, high quality food. Everything was mostly in Spanish but pointing and smiling go a long way.
author: Christine K.

description: Definitely one of the better ceviches I've had! Plus it was relatively inexpensive compared to other restaurants. It was $8.50 before tax. I would definitely come back! The servers were super friendly too. The place is kind of a hole in the wall and seems to be set up in the middle of a random building. Kinda hard to explain. But don't let that fool you! The food is the bomb.
author: Lexi R.

description:
Came here for lunch yesterday on a whim as picaro was closed and this is close to the soccer game we had agreed. Wow the ceviche is great here like everyone says and the chicken rice dish with dark meat is my favorite.  It's located in kind of the hallway of a small strip mall.  Very low key and self seating.  We had six so they pull out the table to help fit us. Everything was yummy.  

We tried both ceviches (I like the first one slightly better but both the fish is super fresh).  We also tried all the meat dishes, lamb shank, pork and chicken. The chicken really melted off the bones.   My old daughter love the pork.  The shank was also good and moist.  

We will be back.
author: Lei H.

description: Cholo Soy is the kind of place which will make you notice that some of your previous five star reviews may have been exaggerated or undeserved. This joint has the best ceviche you can get. Make sure to get the one with pollo Verde and you'll learn what the best ceviche tastes like!
author: Mariana C.

description: For a quick bite to eat done well, tastes excellent, and service is amazing this is the place to go when you're in the Mission District especially if you're conducting business at the Mission Economic Development Association! The servers are so attentive and so caring! Love to patronize these mom-and-pop operations. Little businesses that someday will be the place to be seen and certainly the place to enjoy gastronomic excellence!
author: Jim S.

description:
This place is BombDiggidyDog if I could grab a ceviche from here everyday I would. Everything they cook there is amazing and I would suggest if you are ever in the Mission during lunch time give it a try. 

Only thing about this place is the limited amount of seats...
author: Roberto M.

description: The secret is out and price is way up. Apparently the ceviche was once $5 per a photo of the old menu but it's double that now. Really tasty though. Interesting joint. That's the only thing I ordered. It was too hard to find parking. Would come back to try other stuff. All looks amazing. But the new prices aren't super compatible with the setting though...
author: Xiu L.

description: This place has the best ceviche (both versions) I've ever tried. Even thou it's not a fancy restaurant you still get great service and fair prices! If you want to try a genuine Peruvian ceviche this is your place. It's in a hall of a business building so don't expect anything fancy. Be ready to wait at rush hour (lunch time). Other than that it's a great place. They have daily menus. So your other food options are based on that menu.
author: Gloria M.

description:
OMG, this is what Peruvian food supposed to be, this place got it right.
Super reasonable price, try their Arroz Con Pollo. Their sauce is the best.
Super authentic super delicious!! This place is a bomb!!!!
author: Julia L.

description:
One of those places which make you think some of your previous 5 star reviews may have been slightly exagerated.
This place was a  hugely positive surprise. Inside a half empty mall, there are a few tables against the wall, and a counter of what looks like a cafe in a small town.
In the last months I have tried almost all of their menu (which is different every day of the week). I loved the lamb, the duck (very interesting recipe, with flavors I had not previously had associated with duck), the fish escabeche (only vaguely related to the Southern European, this is served warm), and anything chicken (and I don't like chicken). Their causas and their ceviches are to die for.
Service is great (no special fx, but everyone is polite and kind, and works efficiently and fast).
author: Winter M.

description:
Blink and you miss it, Cholo Soy is a hidden gem that is worth the pause as you're walking along Mission and 19th. 

Located in the elevator lobby of a building, Cholo Soy offers some homey and satisfying Peruvian fare where the menu is rotated daily. I'm assuming they can't really do a lot of actual cooking where they are but the menu isn't skimpy. Lovely ceviche, causas, and lots of stews over rice. We had both ceviches on the menu and they were delicious. The fish was fresh and the citrus juices are bright and flavorful. Love the roasted corn for textural contrast. For $7.50 a plate, I think their ceviche rivals those of fancier spots in town.... and we were just at La Mar the night before. Didn't try any of the rotating menu items but they smelled really good and it seems there are regulars who walk in and know exactly what they want. Looking forward to coming back to try some of those dishes. 

It's a simple operation but you can tell it's a labor of love. The folks here are incredibly lovely and I would love to come back just for more ceviche alone.
author: Jon L.

description: Fast, authentic (as least that's my impression) without the insane markup of places like Pequeños!! Definitely start with the ceviche and work your way through the rest of the menu. Yay for hole in the walls!
author: Andrew L.

description:
A great spot with fast service and great food. I got the ceviche and my friend the duck with rice. 

The ceviche was fresh and simple, with a good kick. Wish they added some avocado, but I guess that wouldn't be as traditional. And for $7.50, a steal. 

The duck was moist and tender and the leg was a beast portion. There was also a heaping plate of rice. Wish the rice was slightly less mushy and could use a bit more salt, but the overall effect was homey and delicious. 

Cholo Soy is a hidden gem in the mission and I hope to come back to try their chicken and pork dishes.
author: Alice W.

description: Hard to find but definitely a hidden gem. Loved both ceviches and the passion fruit drink.
author: Rekha P.

description:
FINALLY tried this place with my beloved who has been raving about the ceviche at Cholo Soy for months. 

It is a very nondescript place, you could pass by this spot a million times and never really know it is there. Sitting in the hallway of a small building, a master chef at work prepping fresh, authentic Peruvian cuisine. Only in San Francisco..

All the tables, chairs and even the bar area were full of patrons eating and chatting away. My partner ordered our plate and we waited for someone to leave. Two seats open up at the bar/ counter.. YES!! 

I had the pleasure of watching him expertly prepare the freshest ceviche I have ever had, cutting the fish filet, letting it marinate in at least 15 limes I watched him squeeze himself plus a secret blend of spices. 

Topped with cilantro, red onion and paired with a SPICY house made chili sauce and peruvian corn nuts. 

We devoured the beautiful plate in front of us, my mouth watering with each bite of the tart-lime juice. Tender fish melting on my tongue. Sharp onion crunch adding the perfect texture. 

I was in ceviche heaven. 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Meghan L.

description: Meet cooked to perfection is how I would describe their meat dishes. We ordered Adobo de Puerto and Chevice de Pato Con Yuca. The meat was cooked just right, they were moist and tender. Order the Cheviche de Leacado too. It is delicious.
author: Shinta L.

description:
It's like street food in the corridor of a low-end Southeast Asian shopping mall. The food is unpretentious home-cooked comfort food. It's not fancy, but delicious seafood for the price. It's the kind of place you could eat at 3x a week if you lived nearby, not the kind of place you take a date.


---- DISHES ----

Ceviche de Pescado: 4 stars
Very fresh fish.

Ceviche Chalaco: 4.5 stars
Very fresh fish plus extra delicious yellow pepper sauce!

Carapulcra de Pollo: 3.5 stars
Very tender chicken but the rice at this place is a bit soggy like the kind cooked in a giant rice cooker. Unsurprising for this kind of homey place.

Escabeche de Pescado: 4 stars
Nice fried filet of fish in paprika / tomato sauce with onions but again, rice was soggy.
author: Letitia L.

description: This is where it's at! Don't come here and ruin the one place in the city where I don't have to wait in line! But seriously, eat everything....yummmmy! Exclamation point!
author: Kristen E.

description:
I have so much love for this place. It's San Francisco-quirky in that it literally exists in a hallway inside of a what looks like it could be a mall? Either way, the staff is really kind and attentive, service is quick, no lines. And the ceviche is so so good. 

I've had a handful of things from the menu but now when I go I literally only order the ceviche chalaco. And if I go with coworkers, we order multiple chalacos, that's it. It's a lunch favorite since I work nearby, especially while doing Whole30!
author: Stephanie D.

description: This little restaurant with food ordered at the counter has some of the best ceviche in the city. Came here for lunch and was not disappointed. Fresh basa marinated in lime juice for hours and combined with cilantro and red onions, with just the right acidity!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Authentic Peruvian food, simple menu, not a fancy place, but the dude who owns the place is a legit chef and is there every day. Extremely affordable (versus Limon) and you get a ton of food.
author: Kaveh M.

description: We really loved the food here. The pork chop and lamb shank (cabrito) were falling-off-the-bone tender and really flavorful. The cabrito I had in Lima was actually kid goat, but that might be hard to find around here :-) The beans and rice were also very good. Everyone here was really friendly and the service overall was very good. The servings were generous; the meals were a good value. Will definitely eat here again. May have to try the ceviche next time.
author: Bob R.

description: Very good authentic peruvian food and customer service. Now I know why it is highly rated.
author: Kallie H.

description:
WOW! I couldn't believe this place actually exists... it's a one-man job with a few helpers. The owner is nice! He works here 6 days a week with 1 day off, so he has passion of what he does! 

Love the ceviche.. and the adobo depuero!!! Which is basically like caldereta (filipino dish) over rice. So heartful and filling!! 

What a wonderful gem and low-profile Peruvian food inside a shopping mall! Will definitely come back for their lamb special on weekends!
author: Jan P.

description: Very good authentic peruvian food and customer service. The owner and chef is the nicest Peruvian man, highly recommended place to eat.
author: Giselle S.

description:
This place is a lot nicer than I was led to expect. It's in the Plaza Adelante at 19th and Mission where they've carved out a space for themselves in the downstairs lobby. Despite how that sounds it's light, spacious and tidy. You can sit at the bar or at the 3 tables. 

For such a small space they've done a nice job of making it feel welcome. Everyone is friendly, there are printed menus with descriptions in English and there's even table service. It seemed pretty mellow during a weekday lunch. No problem getting a table.

The three of us ordered several dishes to share for lunch - 

    * ceviche ($7.50) - I can understand why people say this is the best ceviche ever, fresh fish, mild citrus (not too tangy or sour), utterly delicious. I would come back just to get the ceviche for myself. I loved the crunchy corn kernels and the hotsauce to jazz it up.

    * escabeche de pollo (~$10) - stewed chicken drumstick on a bed of rice or lentils, well cooked but not that interesting

    * carapulcra de chancho (~$12) - two hunks of pork with rice, which doesn't do it justice because it's super tasty and the sauce is really good. 

We all got the chicha morada drink ($2). Not as interesting as I thought. Just tasted like a sweet soft drink. 

Lunch was around $17 per person including tax and tip. But it was too much food. I advise sharing one appetizer and one main dish between 2 people.
author: Jean K.

description:
I eat here a couple of times a week.  This is a good, reasonably priced spot in the Mission. Blink and you will miss it, this restaurant is located in a hallway within a small commercial building.  It does have several tables to seat a few people but it can sometimes be hard to get seating during rush hours.  Otherwise there is usually a spot at the bar.
The food here is perfect, very tasty Ceviche and flavourful daily specials with generous portions.  You can't​ go wrong with the Ceviche Chalaco if you want to eat light and healthy.  The daily specials consist of either chicken, beef or pork (and duck on some days) with a side of rice with sweet peas in a delicious light sauce.  The meat is always very tender and juicy and they get the flavor just right.  Just walk in and try anything in the menu, you will not be disappointed.
author: Tito G.

description:
Thanks to Yelp for recommending this spot!

Had the ceviche as a quick snack. Was immediately impressed by the attentiveness of their staff.
The ceviche was tasty - big tender chunks of fish balanced nicely with the red onion and marinade. Was more filling than I intended.
I was able to chat with the chef for a minute because I sat at the bar and I appreciated his take on not making his food super spicy, understanding that he needed to cater to American taste buds.

I felt so elated when I left! Because of the excellent customer service, their obvious pride in their business, their good food, and even the friendliness of the customers with each other!
I'll definitely be back for a hot meal
author: Sharon W.

description: Authentic peruvian experience. Different specials every day. Very happy, helpful and courteous owner and staff.
author: Leila B.

description: If you're looking for amazing authentic Peruvian food that could be a high end restaurant for its food, this is the place to check out. The owner is super nice and you can tell he cares about making sure his customers are satisfied with their food. I tried the ceviche, crab causa rellena, and asado de cordero. Everything was excellent. This place is one of my favorite Peruvian restaurants in the bay.
author: Antonella H.

description: We found this place by chance.  Delicious food !!!  We had the lamb and the pork.  Simple, but very tasty.  The staff was very friendly and the place was very clean, including the bathrooms.   Will definitely try to make it back.
author: Lisa E.

description: I've eaten lunch at Cholo Soy about 5 times now. Each time the food was delicious and each time I've had to be careful about closing my mouth which hangs open in amazement at how Chef manages to run a successful restaurant in a frigin hallway.  There are 4 tables but I encourage you to take one of the 5 counter seats so you can see how it's done. The menu is limited but guaranteed home-style tasty.  The ceviche is terrific.
author: Hadas R.

description: Amazing ceviche. Great lamb. Wonderful pork. Not a place to miss. Warm and wonderful service. Can't say enough about this place in the hall.
author: Sara Y.

description:
Men love food just as much as they love women. 

Well, maybe the latter more if all women looked like the "most beautiful woman in the world" aka Gwyneth Paltrow. *Sarcasm*  People Magazine, way to tell all the girls in America that the ideal is a Hamptons Barbie doll (sans big tits) who proclaims she "rather smoke crack than eat cheese from a can" or would "rather die than let her kids eat a cup-a-soup". Sorry honey, but not everyone can afford an $800 Valentino iPad case or have the means to regularly fly to Paris for a $70 lip balm. At least she doesn't give a shit about being the most hated celebrity in hollywood. Props to her for that.

Cholo Soy is a place that would get Paltrow's French silk panties all up in a bunch. It's located in lobby of Plaza Adelante; next to Dr. Teeth. The soulful, Peruvian cuisine draws humble working class carb-loving carniwhores. "Carbs are evil and meat is dirty", according to her. Whatever Paltrow, go suck on a cucumber. The rotating menu is in Spanish and offers three slow braised meat entrees per a day served with rice and beans. Appetizers of ceviche and causa are available every day. All the dishes are $5, $6, or $10. Menu: http://bit.ly/1cNrb5X and http://bit.ly/18hpT0e. Cash only.

Their current opening hours are limited because it's based on when the plaza is open. However, the owner told us they plan on extending their hours and open on Sundays in the future once they work something out with the plaza's owner.

There's only three tables and counter seating available so come during off peak hours if you wanna grub in or you can always take your order to go. We grabbed the last available table a little after 1 pm on a Saturday afternoon. We were also the only non-natives there and I'm sure stuck out like a sore thumb but the welcoming owner didn't make us feel that way. This is one of the reasons WHY I phucking love this place. You know it's legit when all the customers are natives and there's not any hipsters in sight...yet.

The only thing I could decipher off the menu was the Ceviche ($5): http://bit.ly/IArVld. I'm usually not a fan of ceviche as I find the citrus to overpower the delicateness of the fish but this one was solid especially for the price tag. The fish was firm and the leche de tigre was bold without causing you to pucker your lips. I love the accompanying fried corn kernels for the satisfying crunchy texture contrast. 

We shared two entrees, the Cabrito Norteno de Cordero (lamb shank - $10) and Guisado Norteno de Pollo (chicken - $6) which were both excellent. You can tell they were a labor of love having been stewed for hours. The chicken was fall-of-the-bone tender and filled with savory deliciousness: http://bit.ly/18hqy1w. The fork tender lamb shank was robust with spices: http://bit.ly/1b9aljr. I normally don't care for beans but the accompanying beans had a lovely richness to them. 

I washed everything down with a Chica Morado (purple corn drink - $2) which was refreshing and not too sweet: http://bit.ly/18b75ms. 

Cholo Soy is the epitome of Peruvian homestyle cooking at its finest. You also gotta love that it's very easy on the wallet. Well Mr. NSS did. Our entire meal cost less than one-thirds of Paltrow's lip balm! Take that Black Friday shoppers at Walmart fighting over the last...toothbrush holder. True story. *Le sigh*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
A few blocks from 16th Bart and you are in ceviche heaven.  We arrived about 11 am and had the place to ourselves.  The chef/owner Yeral Caldas came over and introduced himself and was quite charming.

We ordered off the Wednesday menu and tried the escabeche pescado fish and the carapulcra chicken. I loved that lentils were served with the fish. And the chicken was so moist it just melted in your mouth, the potatoes were good too.

Everything was great, it was clean, the owner friendly.    What more can you ask for in life.

What a great find.  We might go back soon just for the ceviche,
author: Foodlover B.

description:
A little cozy restaurant inside of a corner building on Mission / 19th,  serving literally "the most amazing, the BEST Ceviche in San Francisco". 

Jefe and staff are very nice and friendly. After 20years in San Francisco, I'm so happy to FINALLY discover this Authentic Peruvian Restaurant and I'll definitely be one of their loyal patrons.
author: Nao N.

description: Truly, I should not be writing this review because then more people will find this hidden gem and make long lines occur, but the world needs to know how incredible Cholo Soy is. The ceviche is on point and the price point is the lowest in the city for quality cevice. The main dishes are great too, but to be honest I just come for the ceviche and always leave in a heavenly state. It's a hole in the wall, no frills spot, but with the best (and best priced) ceviche in the city. It's only open for lunch and it's inside the mall area right next to Dr. Teeth. Truly wonderful which will make your taste buds the happiest. Enjoy!
author: Emilia K.

description:
This review is after multiple visits because I'm a good reviewer. 

Best ceviche I've ever had made for me (the ceviche I make at home is still better...). I like the one with the yellow pepper sauce. 

It's not really a "restaurant", more like a non-mobile food truck. Nothing is really 'cooked' there, but made somewhere else and kept hot. 

This place is CHEAP (for SF). Ceviche is just under $8 for an individual sized appetizer portion. Mains were all less than $13 if memory serves correct. 

If you wanna support small business and have, at the worst, a top-10 ceviche in SF, go here.
author: Dash_Rendar _.

description:
As others have pointed out very good ceviche chalaco. I've been here multiple times. Honest & authentic peruvian staples with rotating menus. One of the remaining gems in Mission where food has not been totally yuppified/gastropubbed/fusion-demolished. 

It was a sad moment when the other real Peruvian joint El Perol got destroyed in the fire and the owner can't afford to return to SF. Please, hold on strong, Cholo Soy.
author: Adam X.

description:
The best food from Peru I have had in San Francisco.
The location of the place is not an easy parking  area but it is close to BART and Buses
author: Gary N.

description: Best Peruvian restaurant in the mission. Great prices and service and you'll be served fast... and best of all... great food! Highly recommend this hidden gem! Try to check out their schedule. Love the arroz con pollo or pato (duck) Tuesdays, escabeche (with fish especially!) on Wednesdays, or aji de gallina (type of Peruvian chicken curry) on Thursdays!
author: Miguel A.

description:
This review is for their Ceviche de Pescado. 
I found this place by accident. After a long drive from San Jose and too much water, I needed to find a restroom and this place is the first place I saw after getting out of my car.  It was just meant to be... I am Peruvian and I have been to some of Peru's best restaurants, including the Mistura food festival that showcases the best that Peru has to offer in terms of food, especially ceviche. Cholo Soy's Ceviche de Pescado is the better than the majority of the places that were showcased there and I can only think of maybe 2 ceviche restaurants in all of Peru that may be better.  So if you're looking for really good ceviche or if you're curious about ceviche in general, you have to visit Cholo Soy.
author: Sandy D.

description:
After 15 years in San Francisco, I can finally say I I ate the Best Peruvian Food in the Bay Area...!!!!
Doesn't have to be the most expensive or the most fancy place. But, if what you mind is the food quality and taste... This is the Place... Best flavor Ever... Like back home... I was eating there with my family and we couldn't believe how excellent the food was. 
Great Service, the Owner and his Staff very, very friendly.
Way to Go Cholo Soy!!! BEST BEST PERUVIAN FOOD IN TOWN!!!!
author: Patricia C.

description: I came here today at 4:30 and everything was packed up with one at the counter. You should update your hours if you are not open until 5 pm. Especially on a 80 degree day in SF when people want ceviche. Hopefully I can catch them during their updated hours.
author: Alexandria B.

description:
Awesome food and friendly service. Best ceviche I have ever had. I love eating here!

Try going on Friday and getting the lamb. Fall off the bone meat and very reasonably priced. Yum!
author: Rob M.

description: My official ceviche dealer. I'm somewhat of a Peruvian ceviche connoisseur and I'm HOOKED! The first time I placed my order online for pick up but when I got there I found the place to be a nice and clean little fast food type feel. This is the type of place where both blue and white collar share a table and talk in Spanish about how delicious the food is along with conversation of how beautiful the day is. So, I decided to eat my food there as Cholo Soy had a nice authentic version of the Mission community feel to it. Not that gentrified, hipster feel. They have excellent customer service and although busy, their small staff makes genuine friendly conversation with their patrons. The chef puts his heart into the food as you can see and taste it. I always order two orders of the Amarillo Ceviche and before I even sit down they ask me if I want the usual. I love it! This is the old school type immigrant business in the la Mission that I whole heartedly support and grew up loving!
author: Kristine T.

description:
They serve you up just like your mom would, so don't come here expecting anything fancy.

That said I had the beef and my boy had the pork chops. Meat on both dishes were DRY.

Don't think I'll come back, but it wasn't a terrible experience.... 

Have had better dishes for $12.50....
author: Brian C.

description: Came on Saturday at around noon. No signs of life. Called them and nobody picked up the phone.
author: C B.

description: Ceviche is delicious here! The people here are really nice as we had a really large group. They helped us put tables together so our party could sit together. One day I'll come back and actually be hungrier and order an entree as they looked delicious as well.
author: Julie L.

description:
San Francisco has many hidden gems , but in the case of Cholo Soy it is doubly so since they are located in the lobby of Plaza Adelante, (this is home to several organizations focused on the empowerment of Latino families). It is not apparent that this is the home of Cholo Soy because of the lack of signage, but due to Yelp posters it was my Lunch Time Destination! 

As other have posted, 
There is an unassuming friendly pair that run Cholo Soy, who know enough English to communicate with those of us that have long ago forgotten what we learned in a High School Spanish Class.

But what is great about Cholo Soy is how it delivers quality.
Friendly Efficient Service (I was in and out in just a few minutes with a meal that was neatly, and thoughtfully packaged), 
Easy to Understand Daily Bi-lingual Menus that describe the dishes.
Deeply Flavorful Food ( my lunch of Estofado de Carne / Spanish Beef Stew was well seasoned, presented, and had a large portion of fork tender Beef).

Cholo Soy might be in a humble setting, but the quality of their food, and execution of their service exceeds most dinning options at this price point in San Francisco.
author: Joseph A.

description: Little shop with delicious ceviche, the red sauce is spicy. I'll have to come back for the amarillo!
author: Rohan D.

description:
This is not only one of the best places to eat in SF but also one of the best places to eat EVER! Cholo Soy is a great example of real authentic foods and makes you feel as if you're eating food that's outside of the country as if you were really in Peru. Great quality food with amazing flavors, served fast so you can get your grub on pronto! Definitely a hidden gem that you need to find ASAP. You haven't really lived life and did your taste buds justice until you eat here. 

Amazing food + great service = 5 stars!
author: Sotheara Y.

description: Great little place in Mission. A little hidden which is great because only the ones that know about it find it lol. One must have is the Ceviche Chalaco $7.50 Also ordered the chicken plate ($8) which also yummy. There is also a Lamb with rice plate ($12.50) which looks really good too. Might try that one next time I come. Btw, menu changed. Added a picture of it as an update.
author: Ibelig V.

description: A hidden gem in the Mission. Amazing ceviche and really cheap too.  Sit at the bar and let them feed you.
author: Mitch A.

description: If you can't get enough of the deliciousness Cholo Soy has to offer, they have just opened The Aji restaurant on Mission st between 26th and Cesar Chavez. Open 11am-4pm, then 5pm-10pm. Enjoy!
author: Elliot C.

description:
Riquisimo!
Original North- Peruvian ceviche.
So tasty and refreshing... I recommend the yellow ají ceviche.
Gourmet delight for an unbeatable price
author: Alejandro V.

description: Drove all the way from Healdsburg.. Fought mission traffic, busted rump and they ran out of food! WTF? Spent a week in Peru and never did a restaurant run out of food!
author: Robert P.

description:
Amazing food
Very clean small joint
Welcoming staff 
Clean utensils 
Quality food 
Good price 
Every day a different menu
author: Gurneet K.

description:
I liked it. Ceviche (7.50) is the thing to get. Really good.
Lamb shank (12.50) was also pretty good, and a huge portion with rice and beans. I would get it again, but not husband who thought it was kind of boring. I thought it was fall off the bone lamb goodness. And I dumped the rest of the saffron/citrus juice from the ceviche on my rice which made it even better...

The two of us split both dishes and were full  ( waitress recommended that we split the shank as it was HUGE.)

Too bad they're not open on Sundays!
author: El B.

description:
Startup sensation.

Aimed at a few: www.nytimes.com/2015/05/21/technology/personaltech/a-tech-boom-aimed-at-the-few-instead-of-the-world.html

Aimed at everyone: Few places you can get authentic and delicious Peruvian food for less than $8/dish. This small yet full of infectious energy hidden gem is one of them.

People say this is some of the best ceviche in the city. One bite of the slightly spicy, citrus marinated basa fish paired with crunchy nuts (Pescado) would suggest they are right.

Just don't miss the chicken breast covered with a rich homemade pepper sauce (Aji de Gallina). Surprisingly light yet overwhelming with flavor. Easily my favorite of the two.

Staffed by two people who clearly love sharing the food and culture of their homeland. While Silicon Valley keeps focusing on the 1%, these two focus on everyone else.

Five star sensation.
author: Jason B.

description: I don't know how I spent so much money here when it's so reasonably priced.  We ordered to entrees one pork and one lamb shank and a ceviche.  The ceviche was about $7 and although better than Lolo's I think I prefer Fresca's (albeit theirs is more expensive) due to the topping variety and quantity.  The lamb shank was probably the best dish at about $12.50, and was a rather large portion, however the pork was just okay (and I think a bit expensive for what it was).  They speak mostly Spanish and hardly any English, and definitely a local spot.
author: Tiffany C.

description: It's so easy to miss this place unless you are specifically looking for it! The menu changes daily--I tried the Arroz con Pollo this afternoon. It was a good size portion, the food is already cooked so its pretty fast, but you really aren't sacrificing freshness or flavor. My entree was served with a side of a homemade hot sauce that was delicious. Keep in mind they are only open till 4pm, and closed Sundays.
author: Vivek N.

description:
Hands down one of the best lunches I've had in SF.

The staff is super friendly and helpful if you are unsure about what you want. The service was incredibly fast. Had the Arroz con Pollo, and it was delicious. Key was the Salsa, which is super hot but also fresh, homemade and delicious. Total was roughly $11.

Will definitely be going back -
author: Kevin B.

description:
Came on a Saturday and we tried a variety of dishes. They change daily and on Saturday have 4 main plates. Ceviche and lamb dishes were the highlights. Ceviche was fresh and light. Lamb was flavorful and tender. 

Ocopa was tasty but nothing to write home about. 

Beef and pork dishes ($12.50 each) had good flavor but meats were dry and the sauce was the same. 

We were bummed they were out of the chicken dish. 

Portions were pretty good. Don't expect atmosphere and service is still being worked out. 

I'd recommend passing on the chica and passion fruit drink.
author: Emily L.

description: Delicious food with friendly staff and quick service. Ordered the lamb shank with beans/rice to go -- it was delicious and was a great price (about $13.50 after tax). The dish was big and yummy. Would definitely come back to try other menu options including the ceviche!
author: Siv L.

description: The service wasn't fantastic (they were friendly, but it felt a little confusing how we order and pay) but it wasn't bad either. Food was tasty. Very few seats for such a big place (it's part of a bigger "center" so there is a large portion of space devoted to walkway).
author: Julia C.

description: I'm from California and I came to eat her. OMG a little place that was so good. This man knows how to cook. I also went to LA Mar which is the best. But this place I will definitely come back if in in San fran. The only think I didn't like was the chicha I believe it's powder chicha.
author: Andrea D.

description: Don't know what people like about this. Unpleasant location, indifferent service,  mediocre food.  Very skippable.
author: Petunia The P.

description: Places like these are what make the mission such an amazing area for food and culture. Completely unassuming, this restaurant is in the lobby of some building - if you're not paying attention you'll probably walk right by it without realizing. The ceviche is the go-to dish to get here. The fish is super fresh and I don't know what he puts in that sauce, but it's amazing. We also got the lamb shank which is a huge piece of lamb with super tender and flavorful meat. Also, what I love about this place is that there's no wait - there were plenty of open tables for us to sit at, though we chose to sit at the counter so we could watch the chef at work.
author: Derrick W.

description:
The food here is great
It tastes like Peruvian homemade food
Arroz con pollo , Seco de Cordero and great ceviche
author: Julio L.

description:
Very good authentic Peruvian food and host. 

I'm not sure what it was called but looked like chicken and rice, but Peruvian style. The rice had some kind of beans in it, mmmm so good. A native Peruvian took me here because it reminded him of home, this food is as authentic as you get. The chef is very personable and the ambiance is very casual.
author: Steve S.

description:
Absolutamente the best meal that I had in San Francisco. We ordered the ceviche (which comes with roasted/dried corn, spicy salsa, hella onions) and this to-die-for-(well, it did die) pork dish that had sticky rice and tomato sauce. HEAVENLY!

If you are putzing around in the Mission District, I highly recommend stopping in. You wont be paralyzed by options or by price, as both are modest. Try the Peruvian dranks- tasty and unlike anything we have here.

Everything is made daily by the chef, who also happens to be the server. Yengel is kind, makes you feel welcome, and will have you leave satisfied. Hazlo!!!
author: Laura B.

description: Every time I'm in San Francisco I have to stop and have the best ceviche in town!! And we are very picky and have tried many different places. You won't be disappointed!!
author: Melinda M.

description:
I've always enjoyed authentic ethnic cuisines. Since my cousin introduced me to Peruvian Lomo Saltado - I'm obsessed in finding Peruvian food wherever I am. And then Cholo Soy came along. Finally, a reason to be thankful I moved to SF.

Cholo Soy is located on the ground floor of a plaza on Mission St. Its humble existence can easily be missed. There are only a few tables and bar seating. Except for ceviche - the menu changes daily. So if you wanna try everything - you gotta come every day. Pretty smart, eh! 

We came on a Saturday - we had 4 main dishes to choose from. We ordered Guisado Norteño de Pollo (chicken) and Adobo de Puerco (pork). Both dishes come with steamed rice and beans. We expected they would be good - but we were wrong. They were EXCELLENT! The flavors of the dishes are just perfect for us. The steamed rice is seasoned well - tastes so much beter than a regular steamed rice. I think it might've been garlic rice. The portions were pretty big for the price - definitely worth every cent we spent there. Oh and if you go there - don't forget to ask for their "spicy sauce". But do a small taste test first coz that sauce is spicyyy - it gets spicy when it reaches qyour throat. So good! 

Next time we go there - we're gonna try the ceviche. I bet it's gonna be tasty too. Can't wait!
author: Priscillia I.

description: After reading excellent reviews, I went to this "hole in the wall" eatery with my Peruvian fiance and friends. The food was very fresh and delicious. I thought the  beef stew dish with carrots, peas and potatoes was sooo good (comfort food : )). I had read several reviews saying the ceviche is the best of any Peruvian restaurant in town and while it was quite tasty, fresh and great flavor, if this is the best "Peruvian" style ceviche in town....we were disappointed. The ceviche dish was missing camote (sweet potato) and yucca! Overall, a great spot with fair prices and good food, but someone needs to add camote and yucca to the dish! (There were several markets down the street selling fresh produce!)
author: Julianne S.

description:
We ordered the ceviche and the papa a la huancaina and it was yummy.
The people that work there are very nice and we had a quick service and at a very reasonable price.
We will back!
author: The Bird W.

description: The ceviche de pescado is super good as well as the papa a la huancaina ( don't know if I spelled that right). I went on a Tuesday so they only had chicken on the menu. The chicken was ok and did not like the fact that they give you more rice then chicken.
author: Sarita D.

description:
Best and most authentic Peruvian food in SF!! There's nothing like it! Take it from me, a Peruvian that knows what amazing is supposed to taste like (from my moms and grandmas cooking back home). 

The service is great and the staff is extremely friendly. I've even had the pleasure of meeting the chef the first time I was there and getting to speak with him and learn more about his background and food was an absolute treat!

Definitely recommend this place if you're looking for great food at an extremely reasonable price!

Keep up the good work guys!
author: Marco G.

description:
Simple. Fast. Cheap. Tasty.

Got the chicken and it came out in 30 seconds but still tasted hot and fresh. Especially on a cold rainy day. Finished off with a palate cleansing ceviche which was also good.

Interesting ambiance. Kind of like being in a big warehouse.. Wasn't really sure they even served food there at first. 

Overall good.
author: Tony P.

description: LOVED the ceviche chalaca, which is similar to the standard ceviche but with yellow pepper. The sauce is amazing, I wish I had some bread to sop it up with. Just as good or maybe even better than what I had in Lima. The toasted kernels were the perfect textural contrast. So awesome on a hot day.
author: Derrick V.

description:
As Marco G has said, the best Peruvian Food i have had even as good as my mother's and grandmother's! I live in LA and if I ever find a cheap flight over here, within one day, i would just fly over here, eat some food, drop more money for food to go, and then take it back.

Simply amazing! Chef Cesar is awesome and once you get to know him is amazing. All the locals, with their slang, just really make you feel like you are in Peru!

"Hola Causita," "Oye Choche!" Just some of the things you hear from the locals that just makes it more authentic. Try the Ceviche chalaco; Hell just try the regular Ceviche... might as well be in the port of Lima or Callao in Peru! We were there on Saturday, and their Seco de Cabrito ( lamb shank with rice and beans) was the best i have had since my grandmother passed on over 20 years ago. Even my American wife was in love!!!! 

A lot of people say that the service isn't adequate, but in Peru, service isn't great. That's just the way it is since tipping isn't the norm. Here, you just go in, read the menu and just speak up! That's what Peruvians do! I even had my wife point that out to me lol No biggie! Just sit, order, and enjoy!

The best, simply the best!!!
author: Cesar D.

description: This was a decent find.  We came for lunch on a Friday.  The menu was limited, the food was good, and the service was fast.  I got the lamb shank and my fiancé got the chicken - both were served with rice and beans.  The lamb was more flavorful than the chicken.  Overall, it was a positive experience.
author: Barnali D.

description: I don't want to tell you about this place because I don't want you to come here. Nuff' said.
author: Arthur G.

description: Fantastic ceviche.  Great lamb shank.  For the price to value ratio this place is as good as it gets.
author: John D.

description: Showed up at 3.30pm for lunch. The restaurant closes at 4pm. Walked in and nobody acknowledged us. Walked over to the server working there and she tells me they're closed because they ran out of food. The owner was right there preparing something and the server asks him if there is anything left to serve, he just says "no".  As the owner of the restaurant, I would have expected him to say "sorry" we ran out of food, at least acknowledge the face we came into your restaurant.  It was very poor service. As a business owner myself I would never treat a client or customer in that manner. Unfortunately will not be coming back to this place
author: Christian C.

description: It's good. The lamb shank, rice, and other dishes they serve are incredible for the price.  The environment and location isn't the cleanest, but I dont think I have had food this good for the price.  Definitely a hidden gem. Being able to speak spanish is great help.
author: David L.

description: Best Peruvian Food in Ca.  I Knew that hit jackpot when the cooks from La Mar were on the table right next to me. I won't go into details of the menu. Just plain good food.
author: J M.

description:
This is very authentic-tasting Peruvian food. The ceviche is delicious and well priced. La papa a la huancaina was also very tasty. The menu changes every day. The lamb and chicken on Saturday is very good.

The service is very quick and friendly. Their English might be slightly lacking if you want to strike up a conversation, but I suppose taking orders doesn't require much talking so that's not a big deal.

I will definitely go back. This place is one of the most authentic Peruvian places in San Francisco. It is also cheaper than most Peruvian places for how good it is.
author: Nathan H.

description: 5 STARTS .... Unexpensive, Autentic, Clean. Not your typical Fancy place  but Who cares The food  is AMAZING !!!
author: Daniela L.

description: So yummy and so cheap! The ceviche was super fresh and flavorful. The papa a la huancaina was perfect. The arroz con pollo was good but not amazing. The chicha morada was delish too.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Holy cow this place is amazing! I am reluctant on writing this as I want to keep the secrect all to myself!


randomly placed in a plaza walkway, this little side kitchen is amazing!
the ceviche was so good. One of the best i've had.
the daily dish of the lamb shank and rice and beans was perfect.
The purple corn drink interesting and refreshing.

Owner spoke no english but we were able to communicate perfectly - 

really friendly staff and excellent food at unbelievable prices. 
Same food at Limon, or inkas or la mar would be $50+.

A must!
author: Petri Y.

description: I'll definitely come back for the super fresh and inexpensive ceviche. I also had a braised chicken dish, which was great, but not noteworthy.
author: Amin S.

description: Simple delicious tasty affordable home cooked food. This place tucked inside a big building is fantastic. Had the ceviche de pescado and estofada de carne and both rocked. Big Portions and savory sauces done right. Table service is quick and efficient. Only draw back is there are about 4 tables only. Definitely will go back on different days as their menu changes each day. How awesome is that
author: Matt A.

description: So. So SO good. If you can manage to get here before they run out of food or menu items, I'd definitely get your ass here. Some of the most authentic peruvian food in the city and the guy cooking it certainly knows what he's doing. The service is fantastic and accommodating, the people friendly. They primarily speak spanish/ but understand english just fine. We tried the ceviche chacolo(sp?), causa rellena (SO GOOD), and pescado de escabeche. I WILL be back to try the Aji de Gallina. You can't go wrong with -anything- on the menu! Love love love this place.
author: Ashley F.

description: Good food. Got the ceviche, a pork plate and a chicken plate. Nice portions, place was clean and casual. Big pots of whatever's on the days menu are already made so service is quick. The chef serves every thing from his counter with his helper. I'll be back
author: DJ Madison H.

description: My Peruvian friend said this is the best ceviche she's had... We came to give it a try and by far it was excellent!!! The owner is very humble and friendly... Not to mention the prices are great!!! Kudos to Cholo Soy!!!
author: Abby E.

description:
At first I was hesitant to try the food here. It's kinda hidden between the 19th and 20th on Mission street. I ordered the "ceviche de pescado" and a "seco de pato" I also shared the "ocopa" the ceviche I would say is the highlight it really makes you feel like you're back home in Peru. Fish was soft nice and the ledge de Tigre was super good. The seco de pato was 1/4 of a duck it was amazingly good and they served me like a king! (For $10 that's a really good deal)! The ocopa (it was my first time trying it and I don't regret it! It was sweet and spicy better than the "papa a la huancaina)
I've gone back a few times to eaters stuff from their menu it's a really great spot! Only downside is I wish they had more tables for people to sit in. It is really growing in popularity among not just peruvian clientele but general clientele! Another plus that this place has is the Peruvian regulars that show up and catch up with one another never forgetting to say hi to other regulars in their awesome Peruvian slang. Expect salsa and Peruvian Cumbia to play in the background that will definitely add to your dining experience,(something other places like "fresca", "limon" lack in my opinion) This little spot is the closest thing us Peruvians in San Francisco will get to being back home, I love it! I'm glad it opened up! Tell your friends, tell your family, tell everybody! "Cholo Soy" is here to stay!!
author: Mario F.

description: Ceviche PERUANO. Here's a place to get an authentic plate of lime cooked Pescado. He blends clearly jnto into the lime juice for color and flavor depth. Appreciated. Will have to retune for some meat. Folks around me seemed to be savoring the SECO flavor.
author: Anthony R.

description:
If you are looking for a sit down ambiance filled dining experience, look further.  If you want clean, authentic, and waaaaaaay affordable Peruvian food, stop in and take a seat.  Feels like more of a lunch spot, with plenty of regulars seated at the bar.  Everyone speaks Spanish, but they forgive you if English is your only language.

Came in with my friend for lunch and ordered the Ceviche de Pescado and the Asado de Res.  Ceviche was fresh, bright, delicious.  Accompanied by addictive crunchy corn nuts and a dipping sauce made of pure fire, and I like spicy, so be forewarned. The hunk of beef was easily the size of my head.  Well, maybe a small child's head.  Regardless, one massive portion of super tender braised meat, beans that still had some bite, and rice.  The total came to $15+tax, and it was one of those meals that you have to unbutton the top button of your jeans afterword.  Will DEFINITELY be back, next time with stretchy pants...
author: Michelle M.

description: Authentic Peruvian food and it's delicious! Love the causa and ceviche. Being Peruvian I can attest to that :)
author: Tania L.

description: If their was an option for 600 stars I would select that. The ceviche here is off the charts. Full of Peruvian perfection with great service to boot. Hidden in the mission but well worth the trip
author: A S.

description: Best Peruvian food/ Ceviche in the city! Most authentic here!! Definitely make sure you stop by this little place! You won't be disappointed!!
author: Erika C.

description: This place is amazing! Best ceviche! I love being able to sit at the counter and watch the owner cook and talk about Peru. He's awesome! I'll take this spot over any fancy Peruvian joint. It reminds me of Lima.
author: John-David V.

description: Talk about a hole in the wall in the middle of nowhere. The joint was located in a plaza area of what seemed to be a comercial building. Just big enough for a couple tables and some bar seating. Tuesday 12:20 was our time to get down. Special of the day was half duck over Peruvian rice. I don't know what was in the rice but it consisted of some kind of green bean that was light and not to heavy. The duck was just fall off the bone, juicy, flavorful meat that was finger licking good. Not to mention the sauce that smothered the dish and some special hot pepper sauce to kick things up. We also ordered the famous ceviche that was not heavily tart like some and the toasted corn nuts were a nice touch. I would have liked more variety of seafood in the mix but the fish was all good on it's own. I'll definately come back to try some other specials!
author: T L.

description: This is the best cerviche I've had outside of Peru. Skip La Mar and come here. The fish is fresh, chef yeral cooks it right in front of you, the texture is just right. All the cerviche also comes with fried corn kennels, something I've come to love and have never found in the states other than here. Will go back!
author: Sanny L.

description:
This is a little cafe inside the lobby of Plaza Adelante on the corner of 19th & Mission. Really good! Love it. Chicken falls off the bone. Deliciously seasoned rice. He doesn't cook there so he's actually more like a street vendor but with a counter and tables. 

You must eat the ceviche. I know people in the building who have it 2-3 times a week. Larger chunks make it a meal of its own. 

Owner is a really good guy too. Give it a go.
author: Michelle R.

description: Delicious food.  Such a great restaurant.  I wish they were open on Sunday's so that there would be one more day in the week that I could go there!
author: Carla M.

description: Hi im from new york i've been there last year..and i must say i love the place ,the ceviche is not expensive and has a great taste  and the owner such a nice person i will defintely recommend this pace to all my peruvian people
author: Paola C.

description: Incredible food, simple ingredients with amazing flavors. I don't understand how they do it in such a small space! I had chicken and rice with lentils, ceviche, and the passionfruit drink (yum!). I thought I'd end up bringing a to-go box back to work but I ended up cleaning my plate. I will definitely be back.
author: Maryam M.

description:
Super cheap, super good, super authentic (not  fusion) Peruvian food. 

Menu choices are minimalistic, however what they have is covers the "Peruvian"  basics: ceviche  (only $6)  and  more.

Location is kinda cafeteria style or something like that.  Not a "date place" unless your date is  a relaxed person and not wanting to  be wowed by  fancy decorations. 

No dinner. Lunch only to 4PM and earlier some days Closed on Sunday.
author: Adam G.

description: The ceviche was pretty good. It needed a little more spice in my opinion but it wasn't bad at all. Also tried the papa a la huancaina and the ocopa. I liked the ocopa the most. Service was fast and friendly. If I'm ever in the area again, I would come back and try some of their main dishes.
author: C K.

description: My partner and I have been here a couple of times, the last time being 3 days ago for a late lunch.  What we noticed right away was the consistency of the quality of the food we were served.  The food is prepared simply, like something I might have grown up eating (if I was born Peruvian).  Everything that we ordered (this time we had ceviche, tripe & chicken) were well prepared, portioned fairly and priced decently.  You also get a sense that you're eating at a truly authentic environment.  Everyone around us were speaking Spanish.  And to top it off, there were 2 guys in Mariachi outfits sending money using the MoneyGram machine a few feet from where we were seated.  Now that's truly a novelty for me!
author: Yvette F.

description: This place serves authentic peruvian food at very reasonable prices.  So far I've just tried their ceviche chalaca.  I generally order it twice while there. . It's just that good.  The fish is very fresh, cut perfectly for ceviche, seasoned perfectly.  Does not come with sweet potato.   Also be sure to get the drink chicha morado.  Yum.  Can't wait to try more dishes.
author: Eleanor L.

description: the place to eat. It reminded me of home. Small, simple menu, perfectly served. Clean and organized. The ceviche was PERFECT!
author: Eduardo M.

description: This restaurant is a great discovery. In a very un-trendy interior, pretty much in a corridor, this little restaurant serves culinary magic from simple menu that rotates per day of the week and comprises of breathtaking cerviche (I tried two types) and full-bodied entrees. I will definitely come back to cover all days of the week!
author: Grzegorz J.

description: WOW. Lived in Ecuador (which Peru then stole a large chunk of) and remember eating Peruvian food often. This place is legit. So flavorful it's ridiculous. How is this place not more popular?
author: Jordan T.

description:
Cholo Soy is officially my favorite Peruvian in SF. I was born in Lima Peru and have been to all the Peruvian places in SF at least once and this little place (4 or 5 tables and 5 seats at the counter) inside Plaza Adelante (19th and mission) is so authentic and reminds me most of the flavors of the food of Peru. It's been open a few weeks and I learned that the owner / chef Yeral Caldas is from Chimbote north of Lima. The only sign for this place is a sign on the street .

I first tried the fish ceviche. I always use this as a barometer of the quality of food. My belief is if you can't make great ceviche (Peru's national dish) then Im not going to be expecting much else from the menu. The ceviche here is Swai also known as Iridescent shark or shark catfish. Just to be 100% clear, this is a fish similar to US catfish NOT shark. Its flesh is slightly sweet and has a milder flavor and more delicate texture than US catfish. I like it much more than tilapia which a lot of Peruvian spots use. It was awesome. My favorite ceviche in SF right now. The price is only $5! 
I should mention that this place is super cheap. Coffee for $1.30 and $1.60 and cappuccino for $2.50 just to give you an idea. The most expensive dish is $10. 

After this place passed (with flying colors) the ceviche test, I tried the Papa Huancaina (slightly warm Yukon Gold potato salad with Huancaina sauce. The main ingredients are; aji amarillo peppers , cheese and saltine crackers. Its a great side dish that has a cheesy taste with a little spice at the end. Price is $5 

I went a few days later to try the Arroz con Pato. (Roast duck with a green cilantro rice)  It was a leg and thigh and had carrots and peas tossed in. Great portion size and it was tender and had a little onion salsa on top. I asked for rocoto sauce (spicy red pepper) to go with it since I'm addicted to spice. I found out that Yeral makes his own sauce and pretty much makes everything himself. Price $10.

This place is a little authentic spot and I've seen it crowded with mostly Peruvians. It's refreshing to go to a place with no Yelp reviews that seems to be under the radar. Its SO cheap that I eat here a few times a week now. His hours are 7am to 5 pm Monday to Saturday. Cholo Soy reminds me of a Mexican "fonda" A small place were workers and people go to get a quick casual bite. In peru they are called huariques. Its authentic style dishes, no fusion going on here.

In addition to the 3 dishes I tried he offers Arroz con Pollo ($6) or Duck($10) and tamales ($5) and Ocopa ($5, similar to Huancaina with huacatay mint sauce and nuts) 

Specials are daily
Monday - Chicken or duck Ceviche (cooked dish) ($6, $10)
Tuesday - Arroz con Pollo or duck ($6 , $10)
Wednesday - Fish Escabeche with lentils ($6)
Thursday - Aji de gallina ($6) ( chicken stew with cheese and nut sauce)
Friday - Seco de Cordero or chicken- Lambor chicken stew ($10 , $6)
Saturday - Cabrito de Cordero ($10)
He has Inca Cola and Chicha morada and sodas to drink for $1 a can

This guy is off to a great start and I hope the kids in the mission looking for a break from tacos and pizza will give it a try.
author: Jose K.

description: Their ceviche is very good with the yellow sauce which was also very yummy. Pretty expensive and the other plates were meh. I tried their beef steak stew with Lima beans and rice. So one plate and one appetizer and two drinks and it was 30 bucks. The location is at a clothes mall and the service was okay. I'd come back to try the aji de gallina but I don't particularly like the beef steak stew
author: Karina H.

description:
Coming back from a month long trip in Peru, I've been in search of great Peruvian restaurants. This was great! The ceviche was delicious and for the price you cannot beat it!! The chicha was a little disappointing as it tasted more like pineapple than corn & cloves :( still worth the trip when you're craving some good ceviche! 

Total meal cost: 9.50!
author: Lisa T.

description: Had their ceviche and loved it.  My friend had their chicken dish and he loved that too.  Small little place with a few tables but great food and great price.
author: Jason L.

description: I think this has to be the best cheap Peruvian place in the city. Ceviche is just like what they make in Peru and the lamb shank was great.
author: Matthew P.

description: I love ceviche!!! Their ceviche is closer to Mexican ceviche in MX, which is lime juice only or added with yellow pepper for spiciness. The best ceviche juice is still from LIMON on South Van Ness (my opinion). Fresca ceviche can be more on the sour side, which I still like. I've ordered their food as well, Tues, Wed and I forgot what other day that I came. I DO NOT LIKE WEDNESDAY menu. I ordered two dishes and they came bland, so bland, no saltiness, no flavor, just oily sauce. I would not go for Wed menu. I don't think this is the best Peruvian food in the city, eventhough the price are ok (they just increased)!!!
author: Clemencia S.

description: Bomb ceviche! BUT I also tasted the pork and chicken dishes and these premade meals were lacking in flavor and seasoning. The chicha morada was aiight. Nothing special. The waitress also ignored us and we had to seat ourselves. It was very cold in there too. Unpleasant experience to say the least. No tip was left for her obviously. The interesting thing is that she attended a white couple that came in right away. Wow. Take care your own first you ass licker. Two thumbs down!
author: Genaro R.

description: Tasty ceviche! This place is kinda hidden in a walkway/lobby area between businesses.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Most excellent spot for inexpensive fresh ceviche and the asado de res was absolutely delicious!  Note:  The prices have gone up a little ($2.50 per item) since the menu was posted.
author: David C.

description: The Ceviche is muy bueno. It had flavor y estaba muy well picante. I ate that stuff gangsta style and drank Tigre de leche como un Leon. This place is muy authentic and it is fantastic! Placed inside un mercado en la esquina de la 19th street. Tienen menus different todos los days and it is well priced. I paid 7 dollars American for a ceviche y una Inka Kola. Even though that comes out to be like 19 soles for just those two things, it is relatively inexpensive compared to San Richfrisco prices. I'm glad I found this place. Friendly staff, Chau!!
author: Sebastian K.

description: Ceviche was amazing and so was the chica morada. Definition of an authentic Peruvian hole in the wall!
author: Daniel M.

description: Nice authentic Peruvian. Long wait if not there by 11:30am for lunch
author: Guillermo L.

description:
I have an office in this building and have eaten here many times.  The homemade food is really good. my favorites are pollo (several versions - all delicious) and the lamb ( a bit undercooked to my tastes).  The sauces for all dishes are wonderful. The chef / owner is a very kind person. An added bonus is chatting with the local dining Peruvians who love this place and boast it is the best in the city.  Walk into Plaza Adelante at lunch time and the aromas will win you over immediately.
.
author: kathy O.

description: I've passed by here like a million times but never tried it. I'm glad I finally decided to go in today. I had the ceviche, super fresh & extremely tasty! This place is a simple, no frills, authentic Peruvian place. It's family owened, which I love. I will certainly be back to try some of their other dishes soon!
author: Michi R.

description: Great place! Tiny place but so delicious, perfect place to get a feel of real Peruvian food. Great prices too!!
author: Karen P.

description: I love this place! It is cheap and the ceviche is amazing! The mother and daughter duo is quant and it is in a little bar for quick and great simple Peruvian food!
author: Vic A.

description: Very friendly staff and, of course, delicious food. Don't let the interior fool you - this place is a gem!
author: Mike J.

description: By Peruvians for Peruvians. I don't think there was anyone there who wasn't aside from my friend on a Saturday afternoon. They have six or so counter seats looking into the kitchen and a few tables in a entrance way into a plaza. They have rotating appetizers and main dishes so today I had two appetizers, the ceviche and the papa a la hancaina. They were cheap, authentic and delicious. Minus one star for not having alfajores.
author: Susan B.

description: Incredible ceviche. Other items on the minimalist menu are always great too.
author: Finbarr C.

description:
Authentic great Peruvian food. The people who serve you do not all know English but the food is awesome. It is a must have in the Mission on a hot day. The Ceviche is awesome. They have a Yellow one and a regular one and I cannot make up m mind which one is better. They are both great. I always get the Ceviche and haven't really tried anything else but I have see people order the beans and rice and chicken and it looked delicious. I recommend anyone who enjoys authentic Peruvian Cuisine.
 I like to get my food and go to the Park but sometimes we eat it there. It is busy sometimes but it is always nice. The people who work there are very friendly but when they are busy they may forget about you.
The Ambiance is nice a 3 out of 5 
The food is a 4 out of 5 
And service is 3 out of 5
author: Birdgan B.

description: I was not expecting much given that this place is in the lobby of an office building. But, yes!!!  Ceviche is right on with the right amount of lemon.  The lamb shank is delicious.  I did not like the fish escabeche but you can't win them all.  Minus 1 star only because the atmosphere is so-so in a cool kinda way.
author: Francesca A.

description: We have been going to Cholo Soy since our Peru trip, whenever we felt a little nostalgic for cebiche.  And for the most part we were not disappointed.  It was a simple, tasty food at very reasonable prices in an unpretentious environment.  But something happened in the New Year 2014.  First, while all food prices increased (cebiche's price rose by 50% from $5 to $7.50), the quality ( and cebiche's quantity) seemed to have decreased. The beef and the lamb were just OK.  At these higher prices and lower quality we are tempted to consider the "fancy" Peruvian restaurant on the Embarcadero instead when nostalgia hits next time.
author: Julia A.
